item.title: Tips To Keep You Healthy Throughout The Winter Season - NDTV
item.description:
Tips To Keep You Healthy Throughout The Winter Season

Publication Date: Not specified Source: NDTV

The winter season can lead to various health issues due to cold weather, reduced sunlight, and increased indoor time, which can weaken the immune system. However, adopting healthy habits can mitigate these risks and maintain overall well-being.

9 Tips to stay healthy throughout the winter season

  • Stay hydrated to support immune function and prevent dryness.
  • Include seasonal fruits like oranges and kiwis for vitamin C.
  • Engage in regular physical activity for circulation and immune health.
  • Dress in layers to retain body heat.
  • Aim for 7-8 hours of quality sleep for immune support.
  • Practice good hand hygiene to prevent germ spread.
  • Moisturize skin to combat dryness from cold air.
  • Get sunlight exposure for vitamin D to support bone health.
  • Opt for warm beverages to aid digestion and enhance immunity.
“By following these tips, you can enhance your immunity, protect against common winter ailments, and enjoy a healthy and active season.”

Disclaimer: This content including advice provides generic information only. It is in no way a substitute for a qualified medical opinion. Always consult a specialist or your own doctor for more information. NDTV does not claim responsibility for this information.

item.title: Why Indians need cardiac tests much earlier - The Week
item.description:
Why Indians Need Cardiac Tests Much Earlier

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Indian Journal of Medical Research

Recent studies indicate significant increases in heart disease among Indian adults, particularly urging earlier cardiac screenings, even for those without symptoms.

  • A rise of 3-4% in heart diseases in rural India and 8-10% in urban areas.
  • Indians abroad are also at increased risk.
  • Health evaluations should start before age 40, considering family history and comorbidities.
  • Myths surrounding cardiac tests hinder proactive health evaluations.
  • Early detection can prevent serious complications.
  • Tests range from simple assessments to more complex evaluations.
“If detected early, one can prevent complications like heart attacks and strokes.” - Brajesh Kumar Mishra

In conclusion, increasing awareness and early testing can vastly improve cardiac health outcomes for Indians.

item.title: Women, youngsters, and heart health: Cardiologists call for action to combat rising heart disease trends - The Times of India
item.description:
Women, youngsters, and heart health: Cardiologists call for action to combat rising heart disease trends at TOI Medithon Part 2

Publication Date: [Insert Date] Source: Times of India

Cardiologists have emphasized the urgency to combat the alarming rise in heart disease among women and young people. Their insights were shared during the recently conducted TOI Medithon event.

  • Increased rates of heart disease are observed in women and younger populations.
  • Experts are calling for a comprehensive approach to address lifestyle factors contributing to heart health issues.
  • The event highlighted the need for awareness and education regarding heart health.
“We need immediate action to address this rising trend and implement preventive measures,” said a leading cardiologist.

This initiative aims to promote healthier lifestyles and better awareness regarding heart disease among these vulnerable groups.

item.title: Belgium 8th non-African country to report new Mpox variant - NewsBytes
item.description:
Belgium 8th non-African country to report new Mpox variant

Published on: October 2023 | Source: NewsBytes

Belgium confirmed its first case of the clade 1b variant of mpox, marking its status as the eighth non-African nation to report such a case, as stated by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC).

  • Countries previously reporting cases include Canada, Germany, India, Sweden, Thailand, UK, and the US.
  • The World Health Organization expressed concern over the mpox situation in Africa, highlighting 13,769 cases this year, with the Democratic Republic of Congo most affected at 9,513 cases.
  • Mpox spreads primarily through close physical contact, including sexual activities, but is now showing transmission among children in Africa due to close contact beyond sexual interactions.
“The spread of clade Ib MPXV to new areas seems to occur mostly through transmission among young adults via close physical contact, often sexual contact.” - WHO

This new development underlines the ongoing health challenge posed by mpox, particularly the emerging transmission dynamics in various communities.

item.title: 7 Tips Pregnant Women Should Follow During Winters - News18
item.description:
7 Tips Pregnant Women Should Follow During Winters

Date: December 24, 2024

Source: News18

The cold season brings many health problems, especially for pregnant women who must take extra care. Dr. Priyanka Suhag, a Consultant in Obstetrics and Gynaecology, provides essential tips for maintaining health during winter.

  • Get vaccinated against cold and flu to protect both mother and child.
  • Include nutrients rich in vitamin C, vitamin D, and zinc in your diet.
  • Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids due to dry winter air.
  • Wear layered clothing for temperature adaptability and choose suitable maternity wear.
  • Consider using a humidifier to prevent nasal congestion.
  • Prepare a comprehensive hospital bag for winter delivery.
  • Engage in simple exercises like stretching or prenatal yoga to improve blood circulation.

It is crucial for pregnant women to stay vigilant about their health during winter and seek medical attention if feeling unwell.

item.title: Cure constipation with these 8 healthy habits, improve digestion - Moneycontrol
item.description:
Cure Constipation with These 8 Healthy Habits, Improve Digestion

Publication Date: December 24, 2024 | Source: Moneycontrol

Constipation is a common digestive issue, marked by painful bowel movements, often caused by poor diet, dehydration, or inactivity. Here are eight healthy habits to help alleviate constipation.

  • Drink plenty of water to maintain proper hydration.
  • Include fibre-rich foods like whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and legumes in your diet.
  • Engage in regular exercise to stimulate bowel movements.
  • Establish a routine by going to the bathroom at the same time each day.
  • Avoid highly processed foods that can worsen digestion.
  • Respond promptly to urges for bowel movements to prevent complications.
  • Incorporate stress-reducing activities to promote healthy digestion.
  • Consume probiotic-rich foods like yogurt and kefir to balance gut bacteria.
“If you feel the urge to have a bowel movement, don’t wait. Delaying can lead to harder stools and constipation over time.”

By following these habits, individuals can significantly improve their digestive health and reduce the incidence of constipation.

item.title: Why 2025 is the Year You MUST Unplug: The Shocking Truth About Digital Detox - Edge Middle East
item.description:
Why 2025 is the Year You MUST Unplug: The Shocking Truth About Digital Detox

Publication Date: 2023-10-10 | Source: Edge Middle East

As we approach 2025, the digital landscape is evolving rapidly, leading to a critical need for digital detox due to issues like digital overload, mental health challenges, and the necessity of reconnecting with the physical world.

  • Average individuals spend over 10 hours a day on screens.
  • Digital overload leads to information fatigue, disrupted sleep, and heightened stress.
  • Excessive screen time is linked to anxiety, depression, and reduced well-being.
  • Digital distractions reduce productivity and contribute to burnout.
  • Regular breaks from screens are essential for mental health and creativity.
“Digital detoxes can offer us the space to recalibrate, improve our mental health, and ultimately lead more fulfilling lives.”

Embracing a digital detox is crucial as we enter 2025, emphasizing the importance of setting boundaries and reconnecting with what truly matters amid constant connectivity.

item.title: Eating red meat may increase your risk of type 2 diabetes – not a lot of people know that - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
Eating Red Meat May Increase Your Risk of Type 2 Diabetes – Not a Lot of People Know That

Publication Date: September 2024 | Source: The Conversation

Red meat is a common dietary staple but is increasingly linked to health risks, particularly type 2 diabetes, according to a new study.

  • A study published in The Lancet found that high consumption of unprocessed and processed red meat increases the risk of type 2 diabetes.
  • The study analyzed nearly 2 million participants from 20 countries.
  • Type 2 diabetes affects approximately 462 million people worldwide and is a major public health concern.
  • Poultry consumption also showed links to diabetes, but with weaker correlations.
"The underlying mechanisms linking red meat intake with type 2 diabetes are unclear, but they are worth exploring further."

In conclusion, reducing red meat intake is advisable for better health outcomes, especially in light of the links to insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes.

item.title: Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age - Hindustan Times
item.description:
7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age

Publication Date: December 20, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

As we age, keeping our memory sharp can become a challenge. Harvard University has provided seven tips to help individuals maintain and enhance their memory regardless of their age.

  • Keep Learning: Engaging in continuous education can help keep the brain active.
  • Use All Your Senses: Involve multiple senses during learning for better retention.
  • Believe in Yourself: Positive self-belief can aid memory improvement.
  • Economize Your Brain Use: Organize everyday items to avoid cluttering your memory.
  • Repeat What You Want to Know: Reinforce memory by repeating information aloud or in writing.
  • Space It Out: Use spaced repetition at intervals to enhance memory retention.
  • Make a Mnemonic: Use creative mnemonics to recall information more easily.
"Engaging the whole brain through varied learning strategies enhances memory retention." - Harvard University

In conclusion, by incorporating these simple yet effective tips, individuals of all ages can work towards maintaining and improving their memory function.

item.title: Best exercises: 10 intense workouts for busy people to stay fit - Moneycontrol
item.description:
Best exercises: 10 intense workouts for busy people to stay fit

Date: December 24, 2024
Source: Moneycontrol

This article presents a selection of ten quick yet intense workouts that busy individuals can integrate into their daily routines to maintain fitness.

  • Stair Climbing: Quick bursts improve cardiovascular health.
  • Jumping Jacks: Boost mood and energy rapidly.
  • High Knees: Aids weight loss and metabolic rate.
  • Push Ups: Strengthens upper body efficiently.
  • Burpees: Engages multiple muscle groups for metabolism boost.
  • Jump Squats: Enhances cardiovascular and metabolic health.
  • Mountain Climbers: Engages core while improving mental clarity.
  • Desk Push-Ups: Fit exercise into work breaks.
  • Lunges: Improves flexibility and strengthens joints.
  • Plank Hold: Encourages core strength for a consistent routine.
“A short set of jumping jacks increases endorphin release, boosting mood and energy in a matter of minutes.”

Incorporating these exercises into daily life can significantly enhance physical fitness without requiring substantial time commitment.

item.title: Can a cold actually turn out to be cancer? Signs you shouldn't ignore - The Times of India
item.description:
Can a Cold Signal Cancer? Signs to Watch Out For

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

This article discusses the alarming possibility that some common cold symptoms might actually indicate more serious health conditions, including cancer. It emphasizes early detection as critical to preventing serious outcomes.

  • Chronic Cough: A cough lasting more than three weeks warrants immediate attention, as it may indicate lung or throat cancers.
  • Unintended Weight Loss: Sudden, unexplained weight loss can be associated with various cancers, highlighting the importance of monitoring such symptoms.
  • Recurrent Infections or Fevers: Frequent illnesses may signal an underlying cancer affecting the immune system, such as leukemia or lymphoma.
  • Persistent Fatigue: Extreme fatigue that does not improve with rest can be a sign of several cancers, including leukemia and colorectal cancer.
  • Difficulty Swallowing or Persistent Sore Throat: These symptoms often relate to throat or esophageal cancers and should not be ignored.

Consult a healthcare professional if symptoms last more than three weeks or worsen, as early diagnoses significantly improve treatment success rates.

Dr. Nishith Modi, HCG Cancer Centre-Vadodara: "A lot of colds can pass without causing panic, but there are certain warning signs that require vigilance for early detection."

Being proactive with lifestyle choices can help mitigate cancer risk factors, including quitting smoking, maintaining a healthy weight, and participating in routine screening tests.

item.title: Exercise tips for seniors: Maintaining fitness beyond 70 - The Indian Express
item.description:
Exercise Tips for Seniors: Maintaining Fitness Beyond 70

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Indian Express

This article emphasizes the importance of regular physical activity for seniors over the age of 70, outlining various types of exercises that can promote health and mobility.

  • Engagement in regular aerobic, strength, and flexibility activities is crucial for seniors.
  • The World Health Organisation recommends 150 minutes of moderate or 75 minutes of vigorous activity weekly for aerobic workouts.
  • Cardiovascular exercises that are suitable include swimming, cycling, and walking for about 30 minutes daily.
  • Strength training can include light weight training or bodyweight exercises such as squats and push-ups.
  • Yoga and stretching are important for improving mobility and reducing joint stiffness.
  • Balance exercises, like standing on one leg, are beneficial to prevent falls.
“Exercises for balance, such as standing on one leg, assist people avoid falls, which are a common concern for people in this age range.”

Maintaining a fit lifestyle beyond the age of 70 is not only possible but essential for overall health and well-being.

item.title: 3 Wellness Rules For December: Enjoy The Celebratory Season, Nutritiously - TheHealthSite
item.description:
3 Wellness Rules For December: Enjoy The Celebratory Season Nutritiously

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Health Site

December sparkles with celebrations, uniting cultures in joy and tradition. To enhance your festive experience without compromising health, four wellness rules are suggested.

  • Enjoy Feasts Responsibly: Practice portion control by filling your plate mindfully with vegetables, proteins, and whole grains.
  • Take Care Of Heart Health: Incorporate healthy fats such as avocados, nuts, and oily fish, while avoiding unhealthy fats.
  • Nourish Your Body: Start the day with wholesome breakfast options like whole grains, fruits, and lean proteins.
"Moderation is key, but listen to your body's hunger and fullness cues to avoid overeating."

By following these guidelines, you can indulge in the festive season while maintaining your overall wellbeing.

3 Wellness Rules For December: Enjoy The Celebratory Season Nutritiously

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: The Health Site

This article discusses how to enjoy festive celebrations in December while maintaining a focus on health and nutrition. It offers simple wellness rules to help individuals navigate holiday indulgences without compromising their well-being.

  • Enjoy Feasts Responsibly: Exercise portion control during meals.
  • Take Care Of Heart Health: Incorporate healthy fats and reduce unhealthy fats in your diet.
  • Nourish Your Body: Opt for whole grains, vegetables, and fruits to start your day.
"Moderation is key... listen to your body's hunger and fullness cues to avoid overeating."

By following these wellness tips, individuals can enjoy the festive season with a balanced approach to eating and health.

item.title: Coffee, Tea May Protect against Head and Neck Cancer: Study - The Sentinel Assam
item.description:
Coffee, Tea May Protect against Head and Neck Cancer: Study

Publication Date: Monday

Source: CANCER journal

Consumption of coffee and tea can lower the risks of developing head and neck cancer, including cancers of the mouth and throat, according to a recent study.

  • The study showed that individuals who drank more than 4 cups of caffeinated coffee daily had 17% lower odds of having head and neck cancer overall.
  • Caffeinated coffee reduced the risk of oral cavity cancer by 30% and throat cancer by 22%.
  • Drinking 3-4 cups of caffeinated coffee was linked with a 41% lower risk of hypopharyngeal cancer.
“While there has been prior research on coffee and tea consumption and reduced risk of cancer, this study highlighted their varying effects with different sub-sites of head and neck cancer,” said senior author Yuan-Chin Amy Lee.

The research examined data from 14 studies involving 9,548 patients with head and neck cancer compared to 15,783 controls.

item.title: Yemen's Cholera Crisis: 35% of Global Cases Reported by WHO Amid Ongoing Conflict - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
Yemen faces a cholera crisis; Arabian Peninsula country accounted for 35% of global cholera cases as of December 1: WHO

Published on: 24 Dec 2024, 4:51 am

War-torn Yemen is suffering from a cholera epidemic, now accounting for a significant share of global cases and deaths as reported by the WHO.

  • Nearly 250,000 suspected cholera cases reported in Yemen.
  • 861 related deaths occurred as of December 1, 2024.
  • Yemen accounts for 35% of worldwide cholera cases and 18% of related deaths this year.
  • Inadequate access to clean water and poor sanitation exacerbates the crisis.
  • Yemen’s cholera response faces a $20 million funding gap.
  • Closure of treatment centers due to lack of funds, risking a repeat of past outbreaks.
  • 18.2 million people, nearly half of Yemen's population, require humanitarian assistance.
“The outbreak of waterborne diseases like cholera and acute watery diarrhoea imposes an additional burden on an already stressed health system facing multiple disease outbreaks.” - Arturo Pesigan, WHO Representative in Yemen

Immediate financial support is critical to prevent a worsening of the cholera outbreak in Yemen, which is already suffering from a long-standing humanitarian crisis.

item.title: New Zealand Says Highly Pathogenic H7N6 Avian Flu Has Been Contained; How Dangerous Is The Virus? - Times Now
item.description:
New Zealand Says Highly Pathogenic H7N6 Avian Flu Has Been Contained; How Dangerous Is The Virus?

Date: December 2023 | Source: Times Now

New Zealand has successfully contained the highly pathogenic H7N6 avian flu strain that affected a farm this month, following extensive testing and biosecurity measures.

  • The virus was detected on a chicken farm in Otago, South Island.
  • Confident of containment to the infected farm, all poultry exports have been temporarily suspended.
  • The farm is under a strict biosecurity lockdown while ensuring decontamination.
  • Low health risk for humans as the strain has never been found to infect people.
"We are on track to stamp out this disease,” said Mary van Andel, chief veterinary officer.

The New Zealand government is in communication with trade partners to manage poultry exports post-outbreak.
